facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 96 to 98 of 1964 were filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 96 to 98 of 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated September 22, 1960, and December 6, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax References Nos. 19 of 1958 and 6 of 1959 respectively.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgments and orders dated September 22, 1960, and December 6, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax References Nos. 19 of 1958 and 6 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated September 22, 1960, and December 6, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax References Nos. 19 of 1958 and 6 of 1959 respectively. V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, R. Ganapathy Iyer and N. Sachthey, for the appellant.

facts.text: On April 10, 1953 the estate of the joint Hindu family of which the respondent was a member was partitioned.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. On April 10, 1953 the estate of the joint Hindu family of which the respondent was a member was partitioned, and the respondent was allotted, besides other properties, 400shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd.

facts.text: Respondent was allotted 400 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd. on partition.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent was allotted, besides other properties, 400shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills Private Ltd., and was made liable to pay a business debt amounting to Rs. 3,91,875/- due by the family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi.

facts.text: Respondent was made liable to pay a business debt amounting to Rs. 3,91,875/- due by the family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: , and was made liable to pay a business debt amounting to Rs. 3,91,875/- due by the family to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand of Delhi. On April 14, 1953 the respondent executed a deed of trust in respect of 300 out of the shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills which fell of to his share.

facts.text: On April 14, 1953 the respondent executed a deed of trust in respect of 300 out of the shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills.

anchor.surface_text: On April 14, 1953 the respondent executed a deed of trust in respect of 300 out of the shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills which fell of to his share. The following are the material provisions of the deed of trust.

facts.text: Trust deed settled 300 shares for discharge of debts detailed in Schedule A, which were incurred for the benefit of the Joint Hindu Family.

anchor.surface_text: AND WHEREAS for discharge of the debts detailed in the schedule appearing hereafter, the author number as absolute owner of the said shares has decided to settle on trust three hundred shares numbering 1 to 300 both inclusive, out of the said shares for the benefit of his creditors and other beneficiaries named hereafter and for the objects mentioned hereafter.

facts.text: Debts in Schedule A were made payable by the author after partition of the Joint Hindu Family.

anchor.surface_text: These debts were incurred for the benefit of the Joint Hindu Family of the author and on disruption of the Joint Hindu Family and partition of properties among its members, made payable by the author.

facts.text: After debts paid off, trust to provide for maintenance and education of children and grandchildren of the author.

anchor.surface_text: And after his debts are paid off. To provide for the maintenance and education of the children and grand children of the author.

facts.text: Four persons including the respondent were appointed trustees, respondent to hold office of Chairman during lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: By el. 3 four persons including the respondent were appointed trustees, and the respondent was to hold the office of Chairman of the Trust during his lifetime.

facts.text: Shares to stand in name of Chairman for the time being, who can operate bank accounts, preside meetings, vote shares.

anchor.surface_text: The trust deed then provided In the books of the Company, the shares will stand in the name of the Chairman for the time being, who will have the power to operate the Bank accounts of the Trust, to preside at the meetings, exercise the right of th e vote in respect of the shares of the Trust.

facts.text: Trustees entitled to mortgage or pledge shares for raising funds to pay debts, but sell only after 10 years if unable from income.

anchor.surface_text: The trustees shall number be entitled to sell the shares except as provided hereafter but they can mortgage or pledge the same for raising funds as they may feel necessary for paying off the debts of the author, provided ... Clause 6 provided That in carrying out the objects of the trust the trustees shall keep in mind and abide by the following directions- The payment of the debts of the author as detailed in Schedule A referred to above shall receive the topmost priority

facts.text: Respondent claimed before Income-tax Officer that dividend on 300 shares is income of Trust, he divested ownership irrevocably.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed before the Income-tax Officer, Eward. Amritsar that the dividend received by the trustees in respect of 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills was the income of the Trust and that he had numberconcern with that income as he had divested himself irrevocably of the ownership of the shares

facts.text: Respondent claimed deduction of Rs. 19,856/- as interest to R.B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand from dividend income.

anchor.surface_text: and that in any event Rs. 19,856/- being the amount due as interest to R. B. Seth Jessa Ram Fateh Chand should be allowed as a permissible deduction in companyputing the net income from dividend of the shares.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected claims, holding Trust was fictitious transaction.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the companytentions of the respondent, holding that the Trust was a fictitious transaction.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held respondent had not irrevocably transferred shares, s.16(1)(c) proviso applies.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the respondent had number irrevocably transferred the 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills and therefore by virtue of s. 16 1  c  proviso one the respondent companyld number escape liability to pay tax on the dividend from the share.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld AAC decision on respondent's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. but without success.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to High Court at Chandigarh at instance of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal drew up a statement of the case and referred the following questions to the High Court at Chandigarh Whether the dividend income of 300 shares of the Simbhaoli Sugar Mills, Private Ltd. transferred by the assessee to S. Raghbir Singh Trust was the income of the assessee liable to tax?

facts.text: High Court answered first question in negative: dividend not income of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question.

facts.text: High Court declined to answer second question on deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question. With special leave. the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with special leave.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave. the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Genuineness of the trust is no longer in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Genuineness of the trust is numberlonger  1  53 I.T.R. 195,202. in dispute.

facts.text: Direction for shares to stand in Chairman's name due to s.33 Indian Companies Act 1913 preventing notice of trust on register.

anchor.surface_text: The direction that the shares are to stand in the name of the Chairman for the time being appears to have been necessitated by s. 33 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 which prevented numberice of any trust, expressed, implied or companystructive to be entered on the register.

facts.text: Trust deed is expressly irrevocable.

anchor.surface_text: The deed recites that the shares are to be held on trust irrevocably by the trustees for all or any of the purposes mentioned therein.

Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated September 22, 1960, and December 6, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Income-tax References Nos. 19 of 1958 and 6 of 1959 respectively. V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, R. Ganapathy Iyer and N. Sachthey, for the appellant. Deva Singh Randhawa and Harbans Singh, for the respondent.

The High Court answered the first question in the negative and declined to answer the second question. With special leave. the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court. Section 2 sub-s.  15  defines total income as meaning total amount of income, profits and gains referred to in sub-s.

Section 2 sub-s.  15  defines total income as meaning total amount of income, profits and gains referred to in sub-s.  1  of s. 4 companyputed in the manner laid down in the Act. Section 16 of the Income-tax Act enumerates the exemptions and exclusions admissible in the companyputation of total income in certain specified cases.

concepts.interpretation: defines total income as meaning total amount of income, profits and gains referred to in sub-s. (1) of s. 4 computed in the manner laid down in the Act.

The respondent appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

concepts.unlisted_description: Deems income from settlement or disposition as settlor's income if revocable or assets remain property of settlor

anchor.surface_text: The material part of cl.  c  of sub-s.  1  of s. 16 is as follows In companyputing the total income of the assessee--  c  all income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition whether revocable or number, and whether effected before or after the companymencement of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1939  VII of 1939 , from assets remaining the property of the settlor or disponer, shall be deemed to be income of the settlor or disponer, and all income arising to any person by virtue of a revocable transfer of assets shall be deemed to be income of the transferor Provided that for the purposes of this clause a settlement, disposition or transfer shall be deemed to be revocable if it companytains any provision for the retransfer directly or indirectly of the income or assets to the settlor, disponer or transferor, or in any way gives the settler, disponer or transferor a right to reassume power directly or indirectly over the income or assets Provided further that the expression settlement or disposition shall for the purposes of this clause include any disposition, trust, companyenant, agreement or arrangement, and the expression settlor or disponer in relation to a settlement or disposition shall include any person by whom the settlement or disposition was made Provided further that this clause shall number apply to any income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition which is number revocable for a period exceeding six years or during the lifetime of the person and from which income the settlor or disponer derives numberdirect or indirect benefit but that the settlor shall be liable to be assessed. on the said income as and when the power to revoke arises to him.

concepts.interpretation: Intended to prevent tax avoidance by settlements where settlor retains control or benefit; applies if provision for retransfer or reassume power directly or indirectly; does not apply where settlor discharges antecedent obligation without such provisions.
concepts.unlisted_description: Deems income from settlements/dispositions as settlor's if revocable or assets remain settlor's property

anchor.surface_text: whether revocable or number, and whether effected before or after the companymencement of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1939  VII of 1939 , from assets remaining the property of the settlor or disponer, shall be deemed to be income of the settlor or disponer,

concepts.interpretation: Prevented notice of any trust (expressed, implied or constructive) to be entered on the register.

concepts.interpretation: Deemed revocable if contains provision for retransfer directly/indirectly of income/assets or right to reassume power directly/indirectly over them; actual retransfer or exercise not required if provision exists.
concepts.unlisted_description: Statutory deeming of revocability for tax purposes

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that the expression settlement or disposition shall for the purposes of this clause include any disposition, trust, companyenant, agreement or arrangement, and the expression settlor or disponer in relation to a settlement or disposition shall include any person by whom the settlement or disposition was made

concepts.interpretation: Includes any disposition, trust, covenant, agreement or arrangement.

arguments.claim: By the use of the expression 'indirectly' in the first proviso to s.16(1)(c), the Legislature sought to bring within the purview of cl. (c) cases where the settlor under the guise of a trust seeks to discharge his own liability.
arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso contemplates provision for retransfer directly/indirectly or right to reassume power directly/indirectly; benefit to settlor from discharge of antecedent obligation does not attract proviso.

arguments.claim: Section 16(1)(c) deems income from settlement as settlor's if assets remain settlor's property or if revocable; first proviso deems revocable if provision for retransfer directly/indirectly or right to reassume power directly/indirectly.

anchor.surface_text: The material part of cl. c of sub-s. 1 of s. 16 is as follows In computing the total income of the assessee-- c all income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition whether revocable or not...

arguments.claim: Clause (c) of s.16(1) intended to protect genuine settlements parting with control but circumvent tax avoidance where settlor reserves power/interest in property or income.

Direction in trust deed for application of income to discharge settlor's antecedent debts does not constitute provision for retransfer of income/assets or right to reassume power under first proviso to s.16(1)(c).
Provisos to s.16(1)(c) are explanatory; first deems certain settlements revocable if character described; second expands 'settlement' to include trust etc.
Direction to pay income to wife for maintenance of children does not amount to provision for retransfer or reassume power under s.16(1)(c) proviso (Ramji Keshavji v. CIT).
Irrevocable covenant to pay income to wife does not attract s.16(1)(c) (D.R. Shahapure v. CIT).

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the argument of counsel for the revenue that by the use of the expression indirectly in the first proviso the Legislature sought to bring within the purview of cl. c cases where the settlor was under the guise of a trust seeking to discharge his own liability.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the argument of companynsel for the revenue that by the use of the expression indirectly in the first proviso the Legislature sought to bring within the purview of el. c cases where the settler was under the guise of a trust seeking to discharge his own liability.

holdings.text: The terms of s. 16(1)(c) first proviso are reasonably plain. A settlement or disposition is deemed to be statutorily revocable if there is a provision therein for retransfer of the income or assets or which confers a right to reassume power over the income or assets.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of s. 16 1  c  first proviso are reasonably plain. A settlement or disposition is deemed to be statutorily revocable if there is a provision therein for retransfer of the income or assets or which companyfers a right to reassume power over the income or assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language limits scope to specified provisions; explanatory provisos confirm.
